content: I can Recieve Emails but not send them
creator: morgaz

content: Is there any error message that appears when trying to send an email? You may need to update your outgoing email credentials if they have changed recently. If that is not the case, then there are services online (such as https://www.mail-tester.com) that allow you to test if you can send emails. If the test reports an error, then I would contact your email provider for further assistance.
creator: bbonacci

content: Do you still have the old hard drive or PC? I always recommend making the copy of profile when Thunderbird is not running to ensure all files are copied. If you have the saved profile, you might browse it with Windows File Explorer (assuming you use Windows) to see what is in the Mail\Local Folders folder.
creator: davidsk

content: You must keep at least one, but the others you can highlight, rightclick and select 'remove.'

content: This is your first post to this forum, so I am unclear on where you filed a ticket. Perhaps, if you share more information, we can assist. It 'sounds like' you copied her account information into your profile? Thunderbird is not involved in quota issues, so I will presume that is a concern with your email provider. Details on how you transferred her account may prove useful. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: Do you still have the old PC? That is, can you still recreate a copy of the 2021 profile? If the copy was created while Thunderbird was running, some files may not have been included. A screenshot of the Mail folder (for POP accounts) and Imapmail folder may show what is or isn't there.
creator: davidsk

content: Dear David, unfortunately not, the TB profile has been copied from the hdd of the old pc. Taken directly from the directory users/.../appdata/roaming/thunderbird. I'm afraid that's the only copy I've got. I tried by just copying the profile into my new corresponding directory und alternatively by importing that profile via the TB function. The result ist the same: TB asks for the password, the password is correct, but all there is to be seen is the adress-book.

content:
The 'problem' is that Thunderbird has more options than other email clients and has the distinct feature of allowing the sender to control preferred font without requiring recipient to accept it.

Okay, this may sound strange, but here is the real way to set fonts on Thunderbird. And I attached examples of my own setting of Calibri 14 as my default. Here goes: 

- in Tools>settings>general, set your default font.  - then click the advanced button. Notice the drop-down menu at top. It probably says 'latin' or 'other writing systems' - this is IMPORTANT:  - select 'latin from that menu, set your desired font and font size settings, click OK,  - select 'otherwritingsystems' from the drop-down menu and set the IDENTICAL settings to what you did for Latin, and then click OK. In attached screenshots you will see my latin and otherwritingsystem match.  Notice I also set monospace font. - and, if you have account set to compose HTML, then set that in tools>settings>composition to variable-width and medium font. (You would only change the HTML font setting if your intent is for recipient to receive your preferred font - not my personal recommendation.) - Set Sending Format to 'automatic'

With these settings, your compose window and your sent folders will match. And if you don't write HTML (e.g., bold, italic, color), none will be sent . If you do these settings once, your font will always be consistent. This does not protect you from someone sending you a message in some god-awful font with 30 pt size, but this does provide consistency.
creator: davidsk
